All pseudocodes that appeared in the Algorithms course.



#1 Basics#

Insertion Sort
```{python}
INSERTION-SORT(A,n):
for j = 2 to n
  key = A[j]
  i = j - 1
  while  i>0 and A[i]>key
    A[i+1] = A[i]
    i = i-1
  A[i+1] = key

```
$O(n^{2})$.

Linear Search
```{python}
LinSearch(A,v)
for i = 1 to length(A)
  if A[i] = v
    return i
endfor
return NIL
```
$\Theta(n)$. 

#2 Divide & Conquer!#

Merge Sort:
```{python}
MERGE(A,p,q,r):
    n1 = q - p + 1
    n2 = r - q 
    #divide into left and right arrays
    Let L,R be new arrays
    for i = 1 to n1
        L[i] = A[p + i -1]
    for j = 1 to n2
        R[j] = A[q + j]
    L[n1+1] = infinity
    R[n1+1] = infinity
    i = 1
    j = 1
    for k = p to r
        if L[i] <= R[j]:
            A[k] = L[i]
            i = i + 1
        else:
            A[k] = R[j]
            j = j + 1

MERGE-SORT(A,p,q,r)
  if p<r               #base case
    q = floor((p+r)/2) #divide
    MERGE-SORT(A,p,q)  #conquer
    MERGESORT(A,q+1,r)
    MERGE(A,p,q,r)     #combine
```
This runs in $\Theta(n\log{n})$ time. <a href="https://www.codecogs.com/eqnedit.php?latex=$epsilon" target="_blank"><img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?$epsilon" title="$\forall \epsilon > 0" /></a>

Slow Maximum-Subarray:
```{python}
MAXIMUM-SUBARRAY-SLOW(A)
B.val <- -\infty, B.i <- 1, B.j <- n
for i = 1 to n:
  tmp <- 0
  for j<- i to n
    tmp <- tmp + A[j]
    if tmp > B.val
      B.val <- tmp
      B.i <- i
      B.j <- j
return(B.i,B.j,B.val)
```
$\Theta(n^{2})$. $\Theta(n)$ space. We are simply checking all $nC2$ combinations!

Maximum-Subarray
```{python}

FIND-MAX-CROSSING-SUBARRAY(A,low,mid.high)
#max subarray of form A[i..mid]
left-sum = -\infty
sum = 0
for i = mid downto low
  sum  = sum + A[i]
  if sum > left-sum
    left-sum = sum
    max-left = i
  
#A[mid+1..j]
right-sum = -\infty
sum = 0
for j = mid+1 to high
  sum  = sum + A[j]
  if sum > right-sum
    right-sum = sum
    max-right = j
    
return(max-left,max-right,left-sum + right-sum)
  
  
FIND-MAXIMUM-SUBARRAY(A,low,high)
if high == low
  return (low,high,A[low]) #base case
else mid = floor((low+high)/2)
  (left-low,left-high,left-sum) = FIND-MAXIMUM-SUBARRAY(A,low,mid)
  (right-low,right-high,right-sum) = FIND-MAXIMUM-SUBARRAY(A,mid+1,high)
  (cross-low,cross-high,cross-sum) = FIND-MAX-CROSSING-SUBARRAY(A,low,mid,high)
  if left-sum => right-sum and left-sum => cross-sum
    return (left-low,left-high,left-sum)
  else if right-sum => left-sum and right-sum => cross-sum
    return (right-low,right-high,right-sum)
  else return (cross-low,cross-high,cross-sum)

```
$\Theta(n\log{n})$. 

Naive Matrix Multiplication:

```{python}

SQUARE-MAT-MULT(A,B,n)
let C be a new n by n matrix
for i = 1 to n
  for j = 1 to n
    c_{ij} = 0
    for k = 1 to n
      c_{ij} = c_{ij} + a_{ik}xb_{kj}
      
```
Runtime:$\Theta(n^{3})$. Space: $\Theta(n^{2})$. 

Recurrence matrix multiplication:
```{python}
REC-MAT(A,B,n)
let C be a new matrix
if n == 1
  c_{11} = a_{11}xb_{11}
else partition A,B and C into n/2 x n/2 submatrices
  C_{11} = REC-MAT-MULT(A_{11},B_{11},n/2) + REC-MAT-MULT(A_{12}, B_{21}, n/2)
  C_{12} = REC-MAT-MULT(A_{11},B_{12},n/2) + REC-MAT-MULT(A_{12}, B_{22}, n/2)
  C_{21} = REC-MAT-MULT(A_{21},B_{11},n/2) + REC-MAT-MULT(A_{22}, B_{21}, n/2)
  C_{22} = REC-MAT-MULT(A_{21},B_{12},n/2) + REC-MAT-MULT(A_{22}, B_{22}, n/2)
return C

```


Exponentiation:
```{python}
POWER(a,n)
if n = 0
  return 1
if n = 1
  return a
q = floor(n/4) + 1
return POWER(a,q)xPOWER(a,n-q)
```
$O(n)$


FAST Exponentiation:
```{python}
FASTPOWER(a,n)
if n = 0
  return 1
tmp = FASTPOWER(a,floor(n/2))
if n  is even
  return tmp x tmp
else (n is odd)
  return tmp x tmp x a
```
$\Theta(\log{n})$. 

Alternative maximum subarray by solving the dynamic programming problem:
$$
\max{Sub(A[1...n])} = \max{(maxSub(A[1...n-1]),\max_{i=1}^{n}{sum(A[i...n])})}.
$$

```{python}
DynSub(A)
max_so_far = -\infty
max_ending_here = -1
for i in 1 to n:
  if max_ending_here <0
    max_ending_here = A[i]
  else
    max_ending_here = max_ending_here + A[i]
  endif
  max_so_far = max(max_ending_here, max_so_far)
  endfor
  return max_so_far

```

Karatsuba's multiplication algorithms: Given $x,y$ numbers in base $b$. We have
$$
x = x_{H}\cdot b^{n/2} + x_{L}\\
y = y_{H}\cdot b^{n/2} + y_{L}.
$$
Then it suffices to compute $x_{H}\cdot y_{H}, x_{L}\cdot y_{L}, (x_{H}+ x_{L})(y_{H}+y_{L})$, giving
$$
T(n) = 3T(n/2) + \Theta(n).
$$
```{python}
KARATSUBA(x,y)
```


#3 Heaps#

Max-Heapify:
```{python}
MAX-HEAPIFY(A,i,n)
  l = LEFT(i)
  r = RIGHT(i)
  if l <= n and A[l] > A[i]
    largest = l
  else largest = i
  if r<= n and A[r] > A[largest]
    largest = r
  if largest \neq i
    exchange A[i] with A[largest]
    MAX-HEAPIFY(A,largest,n)
    

```
Runtime: $O(\log{n})$. Space: $\Theta(n)$. 

Building a max heap:
```{python}
BUILD-MAX-HEAP(A,n)
for i = floor(n/2) downto 1
  MAX-HEAPIFY(A,i,n)
```
Primitively, this takes $O(n\log{n})$. However, a more careful analysis reveals $O(n)$. 

Heapsort:
```{python}
HEAPSORT(A,n)
BUILD-MAX-HEAP(A,n)
for i = n downto 2
  exchange A[1] with A[i]
  MAX-HEAPIFY(A,1,i-1)

```
Runtime: $O(n\log{n})$. Buildmaxheap and then maxheapify $n-1$ times. 

Extracting Maximum Element
```{python}
HEAP-EXTRACT-MAX(A,n)
if n<1
  error "heap underflow"
max = A[1]
A[1] = A[n]
n = n-1
MAX-HEAPIFY(A,1,n)
return max
```
$O(\log{n})$.

Increasing key value
```{python}
HEAP-INCREASE-KEY(A,i,key)
if key < A[i]
  error "new key is smaller than current key"
A[i] = key
while i > 1 and A[PARENT(i)]<A[i]
  exchange A[i] with A[PARENT(i)]
  i = PARENT(i)
```
$O(\log{n})$.

Inserting into the heap
```{python}
MAX-HEAP-INSERT(A,key,n)
n = n+1
A[n] = -\infty
HEAP-INCREASE-KEY(A,n,key)

```
$O(\log{n})$. 

Algorithm to sort $k$ sorted arrays into 1 single array
```{python}
SORT(A,L,n,k)
Let C be the solution 
for i = 1 to k
  B[i].element = A[L[i]]
  B[i].array = i
  B[i].index = L[i]
BUILD-MIN-HEAP(B,1,k)
for i = 1 to n
  C[i] = B[1]
  if B[1].index + 1 == L[B[1].array + 1] then
    B[1].element = \infty
  else
    B[1].index = B[1].index + 1
    B[1].element = A[B[1].index]
  MIN-HEAPIFY(B,1,k)
```
$O(n\log{k})$

Algorithm to extract the $k$ largest elements of a max heap.
```{python}
LARGESTK(A,B)
Let H be an empty heap
B[k] = A[1]
insert A[2] and A[3] to H
for i = k-1 down to 1
  tmp = EXTRACT-MAX(H)
  B[i] = tmp
  Insert tmp's children in A to H

```
$O(k\log{k})$. 

#4 Pointers/lists/Stacks#

Stack operations:

```{python}
#check if stack is empty
STACK-EMPTY(S)
if S.top = 0
  return TRUE
else return FALSE

#push
PUSH(S,x)
S.top <- S.top + 1
S[S.top] <- x

#pop
POP(S)
if STACK-EMPTY(S)
  error "underflow"
else 
  S.top <- S.top -1
  return S[S.top + 1]
```

Queue Operations:
```{python}
#enqueue
ENQUEUE(Q,x)
Q[Q.tail] = x
if Q.tail = Q.length
  Q.tail <- 1
else Q.tail <- Q.tail + 1

#dequeue
DEQUEUE(Q)
x = Q[Q.head]
if Q.head = Q.length
  Q.head <- 1
else Q.head <- Q.head + 1
return x

```

Linked List Operations:
```{python}
#list search
LIST-SEARCH(L,k)
x <- L.head
while x\neq nil and x.key \neq k
  x <- x.next
return x

#insertion
LIST-INSERT(L,x)
x.next <- L.head
if L.head \neq nil
  L.head.prev <- x
L.head <- x
x.prev = NIL

#list delete
LIST-DELETE(L,x)
if x.prev \neq nil
  x.prev.next <- x.next
else L.head <- x.next
if x.next \neq nil
  x.next.prev <- x.prev
  

```
Although if we introduce sentinels then it would further simply these algorithms. `LIST-SEARCH` runs in $O(n)$ time and the rest are in constant time. 


#5 Dynamic Programming#

Top-down with memoisation for Fibonacci:
```{python}
MEMOISED-FIB(n)
Let r = [0...n] be a new array
for i = 0 to n
  r[i] <- -\infty
return MEMOISED-FIB-AUX(n,r)

MEMOISED-FIB-AUX(n,r)
if r[n] \geq 0
  return r[n]
if n = 0 or n = 1
  ans <- 1
else
  ans <- MEMOISED-FUB-AUX(n-1,r) + MEMOISED-FIB-AUX(n-2,r)
r[n] <- ans
return r[n]
```
$O(n)$. The key here is that $r$ gets updated along the way so it saves us calculation times.

Bottom-down for Fibonacci
```{python}
BOTTOM-UP(n)
Let r[0...n] be an empty arrow
r[0] = 1
r[1] = 1
for i = 1 to n
  r[i] = r[i-1] + r[i-2]
return r[n]
```
$O(n)$.

When we are calculating an iterative sum $f(n) = \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f(i)$ with $f(0) = 1$:

```{python}
Calc(n)
let r[0...n] be a new array
r[0] = 1
for  i = 0 to n
  r[i] = -1
return CalcMem(n,r)

CalcMem(n,r)
if r[n]\geq 0 then
  return r[n]
s = 0
for i = 0 to n-1
  s = s + CalcMem(i,r)

r[n] = s
return r[n]
```
$O(n^{2})$.

We can extend this to rod-cutting:
```{python}
CutRod(p,n)
let r[0...n] be a new array
for  i = 0 to n
  r[i] = -1
return CutRodMem(p,n,r)

CutRodMem(p,n,r)
if r[n]\geq 0 then
  return r[n]
if n==0
  q = 0
else q = -\infty
  for  i = 1 to n
    q = max(q,p[i] + CutRodMem(p,n-i,r))
r[n] = q
return q
```

or likewise bottom-up
```{python}
BOTTOMUPCUT(p,n)
let r[0...n] be empty
r[0] = 0
for j = 1 to n
  q = -\infty
  for i = 1 to j
    q = max(q, p[i] + r[j-i])
  r[j] = q
return r[n]

```
Both take $O(n^{2})$ time. 

We can also include the cut indices:

```{python}

EXTENDED_BOTTOMUPCUT(p,n)
let r[0...n] and s[0...n] be empty
r[0] = 0
for j = 1 to n
  q = -\infty
  for i = 1 to j
    if q < p[i] + r[j-i]
      q = p[i] + r[j-i]
      s[j] = i
  r[j] = q
return r and s #they contain the optimal prices and cuts

```
Note that for s, the numbers give the optimal cut position for each $i$. Hence we just need to work down the list from $s[i]$.
